description.narrative:
Private sector engagement: An Oxfam capacity building workshop in Asia
Background Within Oxfam, Private Sector work is getting traction. In Asia quite a variety of initiatives are already ongoing, even more are being discussed and proposed. The draftOxfam in Asia regional strategy identifies engaging the private sector as key lever to push for positive change in the region and many countriesengage the private sector utilizing the broad spectrum of strategies (from fundraising to campaigning). At the same time, the overall global recognition of private sector work also was shown by the recent revision of the OI Private Sector policy and procedures document. However, there are disparate views of what private sector engagement means, and our experience is fragmented. With all this, there is a noticable increase in requests for support and capacity building on Oxfam#s private sector experiences, practices policies, tools and guidelines. To address these needs, a Private Sector engagement capacity building workshop is planned for all Oxfam countries and partners in the Asia region.
Objectives The purpose of this workshop is to increase Oxfam#s staff <(>&<)> partners# knowledge and skills to work with the private sector, by enabling an exchange for joint learning by sharing approaches and tools for private sector engagement. This will help Oxfam staff and partners to integrate working with the private sector across various strategies, including programmatic collaboration and advocacy. Own experiences will be taken as starting points to enhance exchange and learning. At the end of the training, Oxfam staff and partners will have a good understanding of the role of the private sector in development and how a CSO can engage effectively with the private sector towards reaching Oxfam#s overall goal: A fair world without poverty. More specifically, the workshop will: 1. Give participants an overview of multiple reasons and approaches for private sector engagement, and an understanding of trade-offs involved 2. Develop understanding of useful strategies and tools, across both advocacy and programming and ability to apply them , looking at various sectors, e.g. agribusiness, financial sector, extractives, humanitarian, trade and tax 3. Boost knowledge on international guidelines and procedures affecting the role of the private sector in development, and current examples of private sector debates 4. Develop understanding of current Oxfam experience as well as Oxfam procedures and policies for private sectorengagement

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Great Britain in Indonesia works with local partner organisations and communities to bring about practice and policy changes which will significantly impact on the levels of poverty and suffering faced by poor and marginalised populations. This objective isrealised through co-ordinated work at both a national and local level, focusing on the improvement of food security, labour rights,institutional accountability, education services and humanitarian assistance. From small beginnings in 1972 the Oxfam Great Britainprogram in Indonesia has developed into an operation which impacts nationally on the factors which cause poverty and vulnerability.The initial focus on livelihoods work has broadened to encompass governance, gender issues, education and humanitarian relief work,all of this being achieved through partnerships with local organisations. These partners share the core ideas and beliefs of Oxfam and are working with Oxfam to eliminate the detrimental effects of poverty.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands
